{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3532435,"name":"Justin Buist","username":"Justin_Buist","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/c77e96/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-19T03:28:51.443Z","cooked":"

Thought I’d start a thread on things people might find useful in simulation. I’ve always wanted students to have the ability to tinker in a virtual environment with the robot for programming. With our team’s switch to robotpy last year and getting my fingers into the physics simulation side of things I could finally see it working.

And this year I think we’re doing well with it. I’m seeing students tinker in the sim to figure out bettering driver controls and solve some pathing problems already.

Lately I’ve been finding out things I had no idea worked. Like taking a Mechanism2d object and putting it on the robot in AdvantageScope 3d Field view. So, I tacked our 2d “elevator/arm/wrist/intake” thingy on the 3d view and I was amazed. I even made a light bar that’s got 100 different “LEDs” to it that just mimic an AddressableLED object on the bot. I also had no idea you could just make an array of poses in NT, tie it to a game piece graphic in AdvantageScope, and have them render out. So, I’m taking advantage of that now, showing a game piece in the bot on the field if it thinks it has one.

Other stuff like in the sim engine if the intake is running and you’re close enough to the human player station a coral comes into the system. If you go into scoring mode and you’re not near a scoring objective both in robot pose on the field and in where your other elements are at, it goes on the floor. If you’re in the right spot it snaps to the correct scoring location on the field.

So, that said, auton simulations can look like this: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=246mQG4sCXQ

Teleop is super fun too. It’s like a little video game.
